docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Commits $3 Billion To Indonesia Aid Package The United States will announce today that it is committing roughly $3 billion in backup financing for an International Monetary Fund package to aid Indonesia.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 A Salinas Says Nepotism, Not Drugs, Made Fortune Writing from jail, where he has spent three years on charges of murder, Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of the former President of Mexico, insisted that $100 million in Swiss bank accounts was ''honest money,'' untainted by dealings with drug barons. He did acknowledge that he had seized the ''huge opportunities'' for business deals afforded a sibling of Mexico's leader. A1 Congress Queries Jiang Zemin The day after his summit with President Clinton, President Jiang Zemin of China sat unflinchingly through a barrage of queries from members of Congress on nuclear matters and human rights issues. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: Investors hammered the shares of Wellpoint Health Networks, one of the country's biggest managed-care companies, yesterday, even after it reported relatively strong financial results for the third quarter.

headline.main: Wellpoint Shares Sink Despite Profit Gain

docs.snippet: Investors hammered the shares of Wellpoint Health Networks, one of the country's biggest managed-care companies, yesterday, even after it reported relatively strong financial results for the third quarter.

docs.lead_paragraph: Meet Dr. Butz, the natty, Scotch-swilling chief resident at a major metropolitan hospital. Played with a gruff avuncularity by a gray-haired, almost unrecognizable Albert Brooks in ''Critical Care,'' Sidney Lumet's bracingly funny satire of the medical establishment, Butz is the smug, genial personification of modern medical greed, incompetence and amorality. Suffering from chronic short-term memory loss because of his drinking, Butz doesn't recall summoning Dr. Werner Ernst (James Spader), a talented second-year resident, into his office, but once the young physician has plopped himself down, Butz turns him into a captive audience for his creepy Darwinian screeds. Even when Werner is desperately needed in the hospital's intensive care unit, Butz won't let him go until he has made sure the patient in need of care is fully insured. The ultimate expert on medicine and money, Butz boasts to his protege that he himself carries no personal health insurance. If he did and became terminally ill, he reasons, his life would be artificially and agonizingly extended until his insurance ran out and the hospital had taken his last cent.

headline.main: Take Two Aspirin, But Don't Dare Call

docs.lead_paragraph: The stock price of Oxford Health Plans, one of the largest managed-care plans in New York, plunged 60 percent this week when it announced losses attributed to a flawed billing system that failed to send statements to enrollees and underestimated payments owed to doctors and hospitals. When Oxford decided to absorb the losses rather than jack up premiums, investors ran for cover. Unfortunately, Oxford's stumble is not isolated. Aetna, Cigna, Kaiser Permanente and many other H.M.O.'s are running into financial problems. As Kenneth Abramovitz, a health analyst, remarked, ''Oxford joined the long list of H.M.O.'s that lost control over costs.'' The trend raises the question whether managed care's best days are over.
docs.abstract: Editorial notes that stock price of Oxford Health Plans, one of largest managed-care plans in New York, plunged 60 percent when it announced losses attributed to flawed billing system; contends that many other health maintenance organizations are running into financial problems, and trend raises question of whether managed care's best days are over (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The bill proposed by Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, that would allow doctors to sign private contracts with their elderly patients willing to pay more than the fees set by Medicare would prevent millions of people on Medicare from receiving care from the doctors of their choice (front page, Oct. 28). Medicare is successful because it limits doctors' charges, enabling the elderly and people with disabilities to see any doctor they want. In the past year, not one of the 6,000 recipients we have assisted complained about not being able to see a doctor.
docs.abstract: Diane Archer letter contends that bill proposed by Sen Jon Kyl that would allow doctors to sign private contracts with their elderly patients willing to pay more than fees set by Medicare would prevent millions of people on Medicare from receiving care from doctors of their choice

docs.lead_paragraph: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that its earnings had dropped significantly in the third quarter, in the wake of a widespread criminal investigation of some of the company's business practices. The company reported net income of $97 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with $311 million, or 44 cents a share, in the third quarter of last year. The latest results came on revenue of $4.6 billion, virtually the same as the revenue in the corresponding quarter last year.

headline.main: Health Giant Says Earnings Fell Sharply

docs.abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp says its earnings in third quarter were $97 million, compared with $311 million in year-earlier quarter, while revenue was $4.6 billion, unchanged from last year; much of 57-percent drop is associated with discontinuation of certain company operations in wake of widespread criminal investigation of some of company's business practices (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: He used to shed his suits on weekends, strap a canoe to his car and head to the Delaware River, where a gentle landscape and the company of friends distracted James Edward McGreevey, ever so briefly, from his ambitions. But even on the river, Mr. McGreevey could not allow himself to float. If there were two canoes, friends recall, he would insist on racing for hours at a stretch. He would study the route like a textbook, craning his neck to assess every bend as his fellow canoers fought the urge to toss him overboard.

headline.main: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: PROFILE -- Politics as Lifelong Passion; McGreevey of New Jersey Is a Relentless Competitor

docs.abstract: Article profiles life and political career of New Jersey State Sen James E McGreevey, Democratic candidate for Governor; photo(M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Assembly passed legislation today to provide health insurance for uninsured children, making Connecticut one of the first states to tap into new Federal money to insure children of the working poor. Connecticut's plan, which Gov. John G. Rowland is to sign on Thursday, calls for both expanding the state's Medicaid program and developing a new private insurance plan that would subsidize coverage for children in families that earn up to 300 percent of the Federal poverty level. Families above that income level could buy coverage for their children at full cost.

headline.main: Measure Is Passed to Broaden Health Insurance for Children

docs.lead_paragraph: Phycor Inc., a physician-management company, said yesterday that it would acquire Medpartners Inc., a much larger competitor, for $6.8 billion in Phycor stock. The combination, which will create by far the largest company in the field, could help restore power to doctors as they negotiate with health maintenance organizations.

headline.main: Phycor to Buy a Competitor, Medpartners, for $6.8 Billion in Stock

docs.abstract: Phycor Inc to acquire Medpartners Inc for $6.8 billion in Phycor stock, in merger that will create nation's largest physician-management company and possibly help restore power to doctors as they negotiate with health maintenance organizations; combined company will have 35,000 physicians and contracts covering 3.2 million people; Joseph C Hutts of Phycor will head merged company; analysts say merger is indicative of growth in power of doctors as many HMO's report serious troubles; Phycor and Medpartners take over business functions of physician groups and represent them in negotiations with health insurers; doctors retain their own professional corporations, responsible for health care issues; some doctors question whether shareowner-owned companies like Phycor and Medpartnes will allow physicians to continue their role as patient advocates while at same time they have obligations to shareholders (M)
